clinical_study.brief_title: , "Mucosal Injury During Nasotracheal Intubation for Dental Procedures in Children-does the Tube Design Matter?"
clinical_study.official_title: "Mucosal Injury During Nasotracheal Intubation for Dental Procedures in Children-does the Tube Design Matter?"

brief_summary.textblock: Comparison is made between standard nasotracheal tubes and a specially designed nasotracheal tube during nasotracheal intubation in children undergoing general anesthesia for dental surgery.

detailed_description.textblock:
The Parker flex-tip, midline-beveled nasotracheal tube theoretically slides past obstruction in the nasopharynx causing less mucosal damage than standard nasotracheal tubes.
The investigators aim to test whether mucosal injury during nasotracheal intubation in children undergoing general anesthesia for dental procedures can thus be minimized taking into consideration adenoid size, and differences in nasopharyngeal diameter.

primary_outcome.time_frame: within approximately 4hrs of surgery (day of surgery)
primary_outcome.description: Mucosal damage as quantified by presence and severity of bleeding immediately after passage of the NTT through the nasopharynx.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: perioperative, immediate during intervention - expected 2hrs (day of surgery)
secondary_outcome.description: Presence and degree of impingement of the nasotracheal tube during nasotracheal intubation

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Participants will be followed for the duration of the hospital stay, an expected average of 6 hours
secondary_outcome.description: ongoing nasal bleeding in the recovery unit

secondary_outcome.time_frame: end of surgery until time of discharge, approximately 4hrs
secondary_outcome.description: evidence of glottic edema/injury in the immediate postoperative time frame

secondary_outcome.time_frame: emergence from anesthesia to meeting discharge criteria, approximately 4hrs

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- children between the ages of 3-11, ASA 1-3, presenting to Wolfson Children's Hospital (WCH) for dental procedures requiring general anesthesia with nasotracheal intubation.
Exclusion Criteria:
- ASA >3
- known bleeding disorders
- recent or ongoing treatment with blood-thinning medicines
- frequent epistaxis
- active URI/congestion/rhinorrhea
- craniofacial abnormalities prohibiting NTI
- known difficult airway
- prior nasal surgery/trauma
- allergies to any of the medicines used in this study.
